titleStmt.title: Unequal access to early childcare: What role do cognitive and behavioral factors play? A PRISMA systematic review

analytic.title: Unequal access to early childcare: What role do cognitive and behavioral factors play? A PRISMA systematic review

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: While it is well-documented that underprivileged populations enjoy lower access to early childcare services, the factors explaining their underrepresentation are not wellknown. In particular, cognitive and behavioral factors relating to information about early childcare facilities and decision-making heuristics have received little attention in existing theoretical frameworks. This article fills this gap by making two contributions to the literature. First, we review existing theoretical frameworks of the different factors underlying unequal access to early childcare services, integrating cognitive and behavioral factors. Second, we evaluate the empirical relevance of this integration through a PRISMA mixed-methods systematic review of the empirical literature. Relying on a cross-validated impact score and p-curve analyses, we find evidence that cognitive and behavioral factors likely contribute to unequal access together with structural factors. We discuss the policy implications of our findings and argue that current public policies failing to grasp the interplay between structural and behavioral factors might hinder equal access to high-quality childcare facilities.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The importance of early cognitive and socio-emotional skills for school success and well-being is well documented in the scientific literature (Heckman and Masterov, 2007;OECD, 2015, p. 201). Attending high-quality early childcare 1 is an effective lever to promote these skills (Bennett, 2012;Camilli et al., 2010;Melhuish, 2004;OECD, 2018;Van Huizen and Plantenga, 2013) and to reduce early inequalities in child development because children from low socio-economic status and immigrant families 2 benefit the most from them (Berger et al., 2020;Downey et al., 2019;Ghirardi et al., 2022;Grobon, 2018;Melhuish, 2004). Moreover, early childcare promotes women's employment, thereby increasing family income and reducing the child penalty (d' Albis et al., 2017;Kimmel, 1998;Martinez and Perticara, 2022;Simintzi et al., 20222;Waldfogel, 2002).

However, it is well-documented that underprivileged children access early childcare less frequently in developed countries, even though the causes of this unequal access are still under-researched (Collombet, 2018;OECD, 2016). Various factors have been put forward to account for these inequalities (Archambault et al., 2019;Chaudry et al., 2010;Lazzari, 2012;OECD, 2001;Vandenbroeck, 2013), but no systematic review has assessed their empirical relevance so far. Moreover, current explanations focus almost exclusively on structural factors (e.g., shortages of places, high fees, etc.) and pay limited attention to the role of cognitive and behavioral factors relating to information about early childcare and the related decision-making heuristics. When these individual-level factors are taken into consideration, the main focus is on parental preferences relating to traditional gender roles, while cognitive and behavioral mechanisms remain undertheorized (Archambault et al., 2019;Lazzari, 2012;Pavolini and Van Lancker, 2018).

This article makes two contributions to the literature. First, we elaborate a theoretical framework stressing the interplay between structural factors and cognitive and behavioral factors. The second contribution is empirical and relies on a PRISMA 3 1 We use "early childcare" to refer to any regulated arrangement that provides education and care for children from birth to preschool age, classified into ISCED 01 (European Commission, 2022).

2 For the rest of the article, we use the term "underprivileged" which intentionally refers to multiple socioeconomic status measurements (mainly household income, occupation, and education) and to migration status. 3 PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) is a reporting guideline for conducting systematic review and meta-analysis that aims at maximizing studies' reproducibility and hence their quality. systematic review of previous empirical research, which assesses the evidence concerning the determinants of unequal access to early childcare relying on a small but rapidly increasing and diverse literature based on quantitative and qualitative research methods.

Our main conclusion is that the existing evidence suggests that, together with structural factors, cognitive and behavioral factors may substantially contribute to unequal access to early childcare. Cognitive and behavioral factors play a role in several other domains, including health, education, and finance (Thaler and Sunstein, 2009). For instance, a recent systematic review of 30 field experiments assessing the effects of information interventions on higher education costs concludes that these interventions promote access to financial aid and college enrolment for underprivileged students only when information provision is coupled with personalized support in the application process (Herbaut and Geven, 2019;Bettinger et al. 2016). A growing literature at the crossroads of cognitive science, behavioral economics, and sociology is tackling the issue of non-take-up by underprivileged households (Bargain et al., 2012;Currie, 2004;Reijnders et al., 2018;Vandoninck et al., 2018) and exploring the role of cognitive and behavioral factors. We contribute to this interdisciplinary literature by documenting the relevance of these factors in a domain where they are still under-researched. This article proceeds as follows. In its first part, we review existing theoretical models of factors driving unequal access to early childcare and elaborate a comprehensive theoretical classification incorporating cognitive and behavioral factors. In the second part, we present the PRISMA methodology of our systematic review of the empirical literature and its results. Finally, we discuss the scientific and policy implications of these results.

div.head: Literature review
div.p: This section reviews the few existing attempts to classify the determinants of unequal access to early childcare (Archambault et al., 2019;Chaudry et al., 2010;Lazzari, 2012;OECD, 2001;Vandenbroeck, 2013) and puts forward a synthetic classification organized around two broad categories: structural factors and cognitive and behavioral factors.

Structural factors early childcare. Affordability mainly boils down to the direct costs of early childcare (Workman and Jessen-Howard, 2018) but also includes parents' opportunity costs of staying at home to take care of their child, which is higher for high-income families.

Accessibility barriers can be traced back to four main sources: 1) Residential inequalities: the spatial proximity of early childcare facilities is important for underprivileged families that tend to be less mobile, but these facilities are less often available in poor neighborhoods (Archambault et al., 2019;OECD, 2001;Vandenbroeck, 2013).

2) Admission criteria: early childcare services often face important shortages of available spots (Jessen-Howard et al., 2020) resulting in the allocation of available places based on admission criteria, which may be unfavorable to underprivileged families (e.g., priority to dual-earner families) (Archambault et al., 2019;Lazzari, 2012;Vandenbroeck, 2013)).

3) Functioning: the time schedules of early childcare facilities may not be adapted to underprivileged families (Archambault et al., 2019;Lazzari, 2012;OECD, 2001). For instance, in these families, parents are more likely to have atypical working schedules (Presser and Cox, 1997), but early childcare facilities often follow standard office hours (OECD, 2001;Vandenbroeck and Lazzari, 2014). 4) Bureaucratic requirements: applying to early childcare often requires documents, such as birth certificates or pay slips, that underprivileged families do not have, especially migrant families (Archambault et al., 2019;Perreira et al., 2012).

We refer to affordability and accessibility factors as structural factors, as they result from a mismatch between the functioning of early childcare and the specific constraints faced by underprivileged families.

div.head: Parental preferences
div.p: At the individual level, some authors have suggested that parental preferences also play a role (Archambault et al., 2019;Lazzari, 2012). Besides the structural factors reviewed above, relying on early childcare facilities can be perceived as less desirable by underprivileged parents because of traditional social norms regarding motherhood and children's needs (Leseman, 2002). These social norms are more prevalent among low-SES and immigrant families (Edin and Kefalas, 2005;Galland and Lemel, 2010;Pape, 2009;Schwartz, 2012). However, the role of these preferences must be interpreted with great caution because preferences may be adapted to existing constraints (Pungello and Kurtz-Costes, 2000;Vandenbroeck and Lazzari, 2014) and may be distorted by (socially) biased information about childcare services.

div.head: Information gaps and biases
div.p: Underprivileged families often have less information about the availability and actual costs of education and care facilities as well as about application procedures. These information gaps may negatively affect their decisions to apply for early childcare as well as their chances of getting it (Lazzari, 2012;Vandenbroeck and Lazzari, 2014).

Informal social networks are the primary source of information about early childcare among underprivileged populations (Chaudry et al., 2011). Therefore, parents will struggle to access relevant information if the majority of their neighbors, friends, and acquaintances do not use these services. Informal networks are crucial to helping families navigate the complexities of the application process, such as eligibility rules and deadlines for applying (Chaudry et al., 2010). Underprivileged families are also less likely to access expert sources (Perreira et al., 2012) available through the Internet, newspapers, or books (Bell, 2014;Radey and Randolph, 2009;Rothbaum et al., 2008).

The resulting information gaps and biases may involve misperceptions of the available supply (e.g., the characteristics of different childcare options), their costs, their accessibility (e.g., the likelihood of getting a spot), the formal procedures to apply, and the informal practices increasing the chances to get a spot (Aksztejn, 2020;Barone et al., 2018;Keller, 2003).

div.head: Psychology of scarcity and non-take-up dynamics
div.p: Information factors may be reinforced by decision-making factors. Poverty and economic insecurity may redirect parents' cognitive resources toward matters other than decisions about early childcare (Mani et al., 2013;Ridley et al., 2020).

Underprivileged parents face significant distress, which can be a source of cognitive overload and of reduced attentional bandwidth (Mani et al., 2013;Mullainathan and Shafir, 2013). They may thus rely more heavily on fast and frugal decision heuristics to make decisions about childcare (Chaudry et al., 2010;Kahneman, 2013). One such heuristic is to 'follow the crowd', that is, the prevalent practices in one's social surroundings, which provides the default option.

In addition, present biases are larger among underprivileged populations because of the life stressors associated with family insecurity and instability (Harrison et al., 2002;Ludwig et al., 2019;Pepper and Nettle, 2017;Yesuf and Bluffstone, 2008). Present bias refers to the propensity to give excessive weight to payoffs that are closer to the present time when considering trade-offs between two future moments. This behavioral orientation has been documented across several choice domains including parenting and health (Pepper and Nettle, 2017), and may lead parents to postpone the application process. Postponing is all the more likely given that early childcare is more expensive than parental or informal care, and its benefits, e.g., in terms of child development or mother's employment, are delayed and uncertain (Chaudry et al., 2010;Herbaut and Geven, 2019;Hunter et al., 2018;Wang and Sloan, 2018). This cost/benefit structure applies to all parents, but it may be exacerbated for underprivileged parents who display lower familiarity and trust towards public bureaucracies and institutions (Bell, 2014;Fuller, 2014;Galland and Lemel, 2010;Korndörfer et al., 2015;Twenge et al., 2014). In the case of immigrant families, for instance, low levels of trust, as well as low familiarity with their host country's institutions, contribute to lower take-up rates of healthcare services (Hacker et al., 2015;Perreira et al., 2012).

Furthermore, the overall complexity of the application process and the resulting cognitive and administrative burden generate friction costs that are particularly detrimental to underprivileged families (Herd and Moynihan, 2019;Sunstein, 2019).

Friction costs include the difficulty of acquiring information because parents lack the time to do so (Bertrand et al., 2006;Shah et al., 2012) as well as cognitive and behavioral costs, such as cognitive resource investment, frustration and stigma (e.g., being labeled "in need" if one applies for means-tested subsidies, Haushofer and Fehr, 2014;Mullainathan and Shafir, 2013;Ridley et al., 2020;Sunstein, 2019;Vandenbroeck, 2013). Lower skills to navigate public bureaucracies including language barriers for immigrant families may further increase the amount of time needed to apply and the related behavioral costs (Christensen et al., 2020;. Overall, social inequalities in cognitive, social, and temporal resources increase friction costs and act as a powerful barrier to early childcare access. Figure 1 presents a synthetic classification 4 of the factors that may contribute to social inequalities in access to early childcare. We differentiate cognitive and behavioral factors from structural factors. Within the former, we distinguish the factors influencing the intention to resort to early childcare from the behavioral factors hindering application to early childcare even when parents wish to apply. Within the latter, we differentiate between accessibility and affordability factors. It should be noted that these four types of inequality mechanisms can interact with each other and that their respective relevance will vary between and within countries depending on structural contexts (see concluding section). In the remainder of the article, we present the methodology and results of a PRISMA systematic review of the empirical studies on unequal access to early childcare. The primary goal of this review is to evaluate the extent to which existing evidence corroborates the hypothesis that cognitive and behavioral factors contribute to unequal access together with structural factors.

div.head: Search strategy
div.p: We first preregistered our data extraction protocol 6 in the Open Science Framework repository. Then, following the PRISMA methodological framework, we conducted an extensive search in four databases (PsycINFO, Education Resources Information Center (ERIC), EconPapers, and Persée) and two search engines (Google Scholar and ProQuest). The search was conducted in English and French between December 2020 and February 2021, and no publication date limit was imposed. To ensure reproducibility, the search results were recorded in a spreadsheet available online.

Our search algorithm was composed of one term referring to early childcare ("childcare" OR "child care" OR "daycare" OR "early childcare" OR "ECEC" OR "early childhood education and care" OR "creche" OR "nursery" OR "early childcare") and one term referring to unequal access ("barriers" AND/OR "access" OR "enrollment" OR "use" OR "enrollment gap" OR "inequalities"). Some optional terms were also included ("experimental" OR "costs" OR "subsidies" OR "beliefs" OR "norms" OR "trust" OR "information" OR "informational" OR "geographical" OR "lack of space" OR "admission criteria" OR "culture" OR "cultural" OR "cognitive and behavioral" OR "social" OR "parental skills" OR "inequalities" OR "underprivileged" OR "persistence").

Two additional strategies were implemented: 1) both the table of references of the main recent articles in the field, and the citations of older articles were explored, and 2) four experts in the field were contacted to provide a list of relevant references.

div.head: Eligibility criteria
div.p: Our population of interest consisted of underprivileged families in Western countries expecting a child or with at least one child of the age to attend early childcare. We excluded studies dealing exclusively with a specific population (e.g., children with disabilities) or that did not cover underprivileged families. Similarly, we excluded studies dealing with access to other types of educational facilities (i.e. structures above ISCED level 01, like preschool). Only primary studies (as opposed to literature reviews) were included. Studies had to be published in English or French, the languages spoken by the coders.
The review focused on the factors underlying unequal access to early childcare.
Therefore, studies were required to empirically address at least one of the factors.

Given that the field is relatively recent, and that the understanding of the mechanisms may benefit from qualitative evidence, we conducted a mixed-methods systematic review including all types of research methods, whether quantitative, qualitative, or mixed-methods.

Articles were initially assessed based on their titles and abstracts to screen out those that clearly did not meet the above-mentioned eligibility criteria. The remaining articles were included or excluded based on a reading of the full text. If the full text was not available, we contacted the authors individually to get it and, if we did not receive any response, the corresponding articles were excluded.

div.head: Data extraction
div.p: The first author of this review and a colleague independently extracted data from the resulting sample of articles 7 . For each article, the following information was extracted: title, publication date, authors' name(s), methodology (quantitative, qualitative, or mixed methods), and authors' primary discipline 8 .

Then, for each article in the final sample and each mention of an element relating to a factor in our classification, the following data were extracted: the countries covered; the data collection method (qualitative interviews or observations, focus groups, observational or correlational study, quasi-experimental, or randomized controlled trial); how the factor was assessed (self-reported measures, objective measures such as administrative data, or both); the type of underprivileged population being studied (defined according to income level, employment status, and education); sample size; the age range of the children. We also extracted the specific nature of the outcome (e.g., the relationship between the belief that early childcare is reserved to parents that both work and early childcare application); an impact score between -2 and 2 (see below), and when possible, whether the result was statistically significant and the associated p-value; the type of test performed and the associated test value and standard deviation, if available.

div.head: Factor coding
div.p: The factors measured in the studies we reviewed were grouped thematically according to our classification (see Fig. 1) through an iterative process. When absent from the initial classification, new factors were added. Once we arrived to a stable classification, we assessed the frequency of occurrence of each factor in the literature.

div.head: Impact score
div.p: For quantitative studies, we computed standardized effect sizes along with the corresponding confidence intervals. The calculations were performed using the ESC package in R (Lüdecke, 2018). However, we could not rely only on effect sizes to quantify the importance of each factor because our review included qualitative studies.

Therefore, as explained above, the two coders independently assigned an impact score between -2 and 2 to each mention of each factor. The impact score summarizes the strength of the evidence that a given factor has an impact on access to early childcare for underprivileged populations 9 . The interpretation of the scoring scale is displayed in The rating correlation between the two coders was strong (correlation coefficient = 0.89, IC 95% [0.85; 0.92], t = 24.2; p = 2.2 -16 ; (Evans, 1996)), which points to a high degree of reliability. For each factor (e.g., proximity), an average impact score was computed from the individual impact scores assigned to each specific occurence of the factor in the literature, regardless of whether the item came from a quantitative or qualitative article.

div.head: Bias assessment among the included studies
div.p: One pitfall of the impact score is that it provides no indication of the quality of the evidence concerning a given factor. Therefore, we complemented it with the Quality Assessment Tool, which is specifically designed for mixed-methods reviews to assess the risk-of-bias of individual studies 10 (QATSDD; Sirriyeh et al., 2012). This tool consists of 16 criteria, each scored on a scale of 0 to 3, that can be applied to quantitative and qualitative studies. Studies are then compared according to the theoretical maximum score on each of these criteria (Hong, 2017;Sirriyeh et al., 2012).

Using a test-retest protocol on five randomly selected articles three months apart, the intra-rater reliability of the first author was very high according to Cohen's criteria (correlation coefficient r = 0.95, IC 95% [0.90; 0.98]; (Cohen, 1960, p. 19)). When the grading of the two coders was compared, interrater reliability was also very strong (correlation coefficient r = 0.83, IC 95% [0.65; 0.92]).

div.head: P-curve analysis
div.p: In order to assess publication bias 11 , we performed p-curve analyses 12 on the available sample of p-values (Simonsohn et al., 2014). Based on the distribution of the p-values below the significance threshold, this method allowed us to estimate whether an existing result emerging from the review could be due to p-hacking, i.e. the practice of selectively reporting analyses only if the resulting p-value falls below the usual 5% statistical significance threshold (Head et al., 2015;Simonsohn et al., 2014). This practice could be due to the preference of journals for publishing positive results (Rosenthal, 1979). During the inclusion phase, 3,695 articles were identified. Once duplicates were removed, this number was reduced to 525 studies. These 525 articles were then included or excluded based on their titles and abstracts. Following this screening phase, 452 articles were excluded, and 72 were retained for the eligibility phase.

div.head: Systematic search results
div.p: were fully read during the eligibility phase. At the end of this phase, 40 items were excluded because they did not meet our eligibility criteria as detailed in figure 2. The remaining 27 articles were included in the systematic review. This relatively low number of eligible articles suggests that unequal access to early childcare is still a largely under-researched topic despite its policy relevance. .92], t = 24.2; p = 2.2 -16 ; (Evans, 1996)). For the risk-of-bias assessment tool, the interrater reliability of the QATSDD was also strong (correlation coefficient r = 0.83, IC 95%

div.head: Individual study results
div.p: Empirical classification of the factors Figure 4 presents the factors underlying unequal access to early childcare that were found in the selected studies. Three factors that were initially present in our classification ended up not being covered by any existing study (decision heuristics and bureaucratic barriers). Two factors were only covered by qualitative evidence (role of information and of access criteria), which means that the empirical basis is quite weak. One factor that had not been included in the initial classification was added through the review process. Indeed, 29% of the articles identified perceived quality as a relevant factor contributing to access dynamics, making it the third most commonly studied factor in the cognitive and behavioral category.
Empirical evaluation of the cognitive and behavioral factors.

div.head: Relevance of cognitive and behavioral factors
div.p: Despite their absence in previous theoretical frameworks, cognitive and behavioral factors were often investigated in the reviewed empirical studies, as shown in Figure 3. In particular, parents' resources and skills to cope with the administrative application process were the most frequently treated factors. Vandenbroeck et al. (2008) show that underprivileged parents make less use of internet websites providing information about available early childcare providers. They also have fewer social resources to help them and give them relevant information about early childcare (Grace et al., 2014;Holloway, 1998;Skattebol, 2016). Besides, early childcare appears to be less of a priority for some parents, not because of a lack of interest, but rather because economic and social struggles leave them with fewer mental resources to allocate to these issues (Binet, 2003;Skattebol, 2016). Moreover, there is evidence that underprivileged parents sometimes give up their application because of difficulties with the paperwork (Grace et al., 2014;Greenberg, 2016;Wolf et al., 2020). Finally, they seem less effective in the application process, they apply mainly later and to fewer early childcare options (Vandenbroeck et al., , 2008.

The perceived quality, accessibility, and affordability of early childcare are found to substantially contribute to unequal access (Binet, 2003;Greenberg, 2016;Van Lancker and Ghysels, 2016). Perceived accessibility was systematically lower for underprivileged parents even in countries where access is relatively high (Ünver et al., 2018;Zangger and Widmer, 2020). In particular, low perceived accessibility due to a lack of places increased reluctance to apply among underprivileged parents because obtaining a spot seemed impossible (Binet, 2003;Greenberg, 2016). Unemployed mothers also reported the feeling of "stealing the place" to employed ones (Binet, 2003). Moreover, underprivileged parents reported a lack of information about the supply of early childcare, its costs, and the related subsidies and opportunities for financial aid (Binet, 2003;Greenberg, 2016;Holloway, 1998;Skattebol, 2016). Free access fosters applications for low-SES parents, but even in countries where early childcare is universal, they may not be aware that this is the case (Binet, 2003;Greenberg, 2016).
Impact score

As Figure 5 shows, each cognitive or behavioral factor reported in the empirical literature appeared to impact early childcare access for underprivileged families. No significant difference was found in the mean impact score between cognitive and behavioral factors and structural factors (M cog. and behavioral = 1.54, M structural = 1.53; t value = -1.13; p > 0.1; N = 156) 13 . Figure 5 graphically represents the number of articles that mention each factor, according to its mean impact score and related risk of bias. Thus, studies using very different protocols concluded that cognitive and behavioral factors influenced access to early childcare for underprivileged populations together with structural factors.

Turning to the quality of the evidence, cognitive and behavioral factors are marginally more prone to publication bias than structural factors, but this difference is not statistically significant (MQATSDD cog. and behavioral = 58.8; MQATSDD structural = 62.2; t = -0.76; p > 0.1).

div.head: The heterogeneity of the cognitive and behavioral factors across social groups
div.p: The importance of some cognitive and behavioral factors varied depending on how the underprivileged populations were defined. In particular, some factors seem to matter more for immigrant families. For instance, difficulties with administrative procedures and linguistic barriers were more prevalent among migrant populations than they were among native low-educated and low-income families (Greenberg, 2016;Johnson et al., 2017;Kahn and Greenberg, 2010). The importance of trust to explain inequalities also seemed to be more relevant among immigrant families, while its significance appeared to be limited among native low-SES families. (Grace et al., 2014;Greenberg, 2016;Johnson et al., 2017). The native mothers interviewed by Binet (2003) perceived early childcare as an educational service promoting their children's development and complementing what their kids could experience at home. Conversely, having more informal care options (e.g., unemployed relatives) competing with childcare facilities is a factor that matters more for low-educated and low-income populations, and less for 13 The results presented in this section are based on the mean between the coding of coder 1 and the mean of coder 2. The results hold when the analyses are run independently on coder 1 data as well as on coder 2 data (see the supplementary materials for a comparison of the results obtained in each case).

immigrant families that can less often rely on this informal network of support (Holloway, 1998;. Unfortunately, the migration background was too small and diverse to differentiate the analyses by country of origin. Figure 6 summarizes the main factors of the cognitive and behavioral factors found in the pool of articles as well as their importance across sub-groups. Robustness checks

div.head: Publication bias
div.p: We performed p-curve analyses (Simonsohn et al., 2014) to assess whether the overall abundance of positive results concerning the determinants of access to early childcare was due to publication bias. Because of an insufficient reporting of exact p-values in the articles reviewed, p-curves could not be graphically represented. The available pvalues were thus first grouped into two broad factor categories due to their limited number: cognitive and behavioral factors and structural factors. Significant p-values were then aggregated into two groups: those below 0.01 and those between 0.01 and 0.05. One p-value per article in each category was then randomly drawn. A Bernoulli test was performed to determine whether the proportion of p-values below 0.01 was significantly different from 20%. Indeed, under the null hypothesis, i.e., in the absence of an effect, the proportion of p-values lower than 0.01 should be equal to 20% if we expect p-values lower than 0.05 to be randomly distributed. The random draw was then repeated 100 times, followed by the Bernoulli test. The full results and details of the procedure are presented in the supplementary materials. Both the impact score and the p-curve analyses concluded to a causal impact of cognitive and behavioral factors on underprivileged populations' access to early childcare: 98% of the replications of the p-curve analyses validated the relevance of the effects of cognitive and behavioral factors.

div.head: Data type
div.p: To test the sensitivity of the results to the coding process, the analyses presented in the article were reproduced independently on (1) coder's 1 results, (2) coder's 2 results,

(3) an aggregated measure constructed from both, and (4) while excluding qualitative evidence. The results were very similar to the ones displayed above. The detailed results and additional figures are reported in the supplementary materials.

div.head: Impact score scale
div.p: Finally, we tested whether the results are sensitive to our coding scale of the impact score. Therefore, we reproduced the analyses using a coding scale only ranging from -1 to +1 instead of -2 to +2. Again, the results were very similar to the ones displayed above (see supplementary materials).

div.head: Discussion and conclusion
div.p: The goal of this study was to develop a theoretical framework integrating cognitive and behavioral factors and structural factors to explain unequal access to early childcare, and to assess the relative relevance of these factors using a PRISMA systematic review. While the importance of early childcare for promoting child development and alleviating poverty is widely recognized, we still know too little about the barriers hindering access for underprivileged families. Since cognitive and behavioral factors had never been previously taken into account in this research field, we discussed how they may affect unequal access to early childcare and then reviewed the small but emergent literature that has developed in the last decade to fill this gap.

Based on empirical evidence, we find that cognitive and behavioral factors play a significant role in unequal access to early childcare. Every cognitive and behavioral factor included in the review contributed to access inequalities among underprivileged families. First, parents' resources and skills to navigate the enrollment process are crucial. Underprivileged parents often lack informational resources and social support, which contributes to hindering enrollment because of late and limited applications.

Perceived quality, accessibility, and affordability of early childcare also emerged as important factors. Underprivileged parents indeed report lower accessibility due to limited spots and a sense of competition with employed parents. Lack of information on availability, costs, subsidies, and financial aid also contributed to inequality. Even in countries with universal early childcare, underprivileged parents have limited awareness of free options.

Our study revealed heterogeneity in the effect of cognitive and behavioral factors effects across underprivileged populations. Factors such as difficulties with administrative procedures and language barriers are more prevalent among immigrant families, while the presence of informal care options has a larger impact on loweducated and low-income populations.

Our study also revealed important research gaps and limitations. For instance, the impact of decision heuristics or opportunity costs has not been studied despite their potential role. Our study also suffers from several limitations, which will need to be addressed in future work. First, all studies used income level or employment status to categorize families as "underprivileged" but both measures raise issues of reverse causality because access to early childcare can impact income and employment status (Abrassart and Bonoli, 2015;. Measures such as parental education or migration status are therefore better when longitudinal data cannot be collected. Moreover, some studies are based on self-reported measures of access to early childcare, while others use external measures derived from administrative data, and the results based on these two types of measures may be discordant, as reported by . Furthermore, all reviewed studies are retrospective, that is, they were conducted after childcare choices had been made (Chaudry et al., 2010;Pungello and Kurtz-Costes, 2000). This is problematic because access to early childcare may modify parents' preferences and beliefs. Overall, future research should rely more on longitudinal and administrative data to reach stronger conclusions. European countries. Introducing for-profit early childcare facilities tends to decrease perceived and actual accessibility for underprivileged families (Pennerstorfer and Pennerstorfer, 2021;Ünver et al., 2018). Accessibility is higher for underprivileged families in countries where having a place is listed as an opposable right (Ünver et al., 2018;Van Lancker, 2018;Van Lancker and Ghysels, 2016). In terms of funding, perceived affordability for underprivileged families increases as the amount of state spending per child increases (Ünver et al., 2018;Van Lancker, 2018).

Despite these limitations, this literature review provides evidence of the importance of cognitive and behavioral factors. If this result is confirmed by future research, it may have significant policy implications. First, we should expect that policies tackling structural barriers while ignoring cognitive and behavioral barriers will likely prove insufficient to close the access gap. For example, Van Lancker & Ghysels (2016) found that financial subsidies implemented on the demand side (e.g., tax deductions, ex-post allowances, etc.) are much less effective than are those operating on the supply side (e.g., subsidies paid directly to early childcare services). The former generates an additional cognitive and financial burden for parents as they must apply for these subsidies and pay childcare fees up front (Christensen et al., 2020;Herd and Moynihan, 2019).

Incorporating cognitive and behavioral factors in the design of public policies requires proactive information campaigns targeting underprivileged families (Archambault et al., 2019;Bennett, 2012;Sandstrom et al., 2022;Van Lancker, 2018) concerning the functioning of these services, their costs, the eligibility criteria and application procedures. Assuming that all families are perfectly informed is unrealistic and contributes to the access gap. To our knowledge, only three studies 14 have explicitly targeted informational barriers to lower the access gap in early childcare (Dechausay and Anzelone, 2016;Hermes et al., 2021;Weixler et al., 2020). However, providing information may not be enough (Bettinger et al., 2009;Herbaut and Geven, 2019) and administrative support during the application process might be a necessary complement. For instance, Hermes et al. (2021) found that reducing behavioral barriers during the application process increased underprivileged families' application rates by 21 percentage points and their enrollment rates by 16pp, while more affluent families were not affected by the treatment. Finally, migrant populations, for whom barriers vary at least in magnitude if not in nature, could be the focus of specific interventions concerning for instance different types of information and language support (Fenech and Skattebol 2019).

This review also found that factors relating to early childcare quality are an important source of concern for underprivileged families, sometimes even more than direct costs (Grace et al., 2014;Vandenbroeck et al., 2008). Given that underprivileged families often access lower-quality early childcare, improving the quality of early childcare in disadvantaged areas is a priority and providing transparent information about quality standards (Becker and Schober, 2017;Ruzek et al., 2014). Recent work has emphasized the need to standardize training and raise awareness among early childcare staff so they can best meet the needs of parents and children from underprivileged backgrounds (Archambault et al., 2019;Marshall et al., 2013).

figure.head: Figure 1 -
figure.figDesc: Classification of the different factors underlying early childcare access 5

figure.head: Figure 3
figure.figDesc: presents an overview of these 27 articles, of which six are qualitative and two use mixed methods. This literature is recent, as 89% of the studies were published between 2010 and 2021. Half of these studies were carried out in the US or UK (7 articles each). The category "underprivileged population" was mainly operationalized in terms of income (in 18 of 27 articles), educational level (10 articles), employment status (5 articles), and migration background (5 articles). A majority of the articles (16 of 27) are based on observational or correlational data and two-thirds (18 of 27) rely on self-reported outcomes.

figure.head: Figure 3 -
figure.figDesc: The reviewed studies by publication date, country, research discipline, evidence type, experimental design type, measurement type, number of participants, operationalization of "underprivileged populations" and risk of bias Empirical evaluation of the classification Empirical validation of the measurements The reproducibility of the assessments was assessed by comparing the scores assigned by the two independent coders. For the impact score, the inter-rater reliability was strong according to Cohen's criteria (correlation coefficient r = 0.89, IC 95% [0.85; 0

figure.head: Figure
figure.figDesc: Figure 4-Classification of the factors contributing to unequal access to EC according to their frequency

figure.head: Figure 5 -
figure.figDesc: Number of articles mentioning each factor, according to the mean impact score and risk of bias

figure.head: Figure 6 -
figure.figDesc: Heterogeneity of the cognitive and behavioral factors found in the literature across different types of underprivileged populations (i.e., whether they are defined in terms of migration background or socioeconomic background)

Finally, only a small fraction of countries were represented in this review, which reduces its external validity. As the respective weight of factors can vary considerably according to institutional contexts, replicating studies across different institutional contexts would allow exploring how the relative weight of different structural and cognitive, and behavioral factors varies cross-nationally (Van Lancker, 2018; Van Lancker and Ghysels, 2016). For instance, Ünver et al. (2018) highlighted strong variations in perceived accessibility according to the institutional characteristics of various

row.cell: mentioned by more than a third

figure.figDesc: average impact score and their risk of bias. The impact score is a metric that sought to assess what a piece of evidence concludes about the differential effect of a given factor on access to EC for underprivileged populations compared to more well-off populations.
figure.note: 4-Classification of the factors contributing to unequal access to EC according to their frequency in the empirical literature, whether they were only covered by qualitative evidence or not, their

body.note: This general classification synthesizes the contributions of existing frameworks to which cognitive and behavioral factors are added.5 Perceived quality was not initially present in our classification (see Results).
Even though we did not deviate from our preregistered protocol, our terminology evolved during data collection.

See the OSF project for data and scripts 8 The article's discipline was finally defined according to that of the first author, rather than that of the journal to deal with interdisciplinary journals and unpublished manuscripts.
The scoring scale's details are available in the supplementary materials.
See the supplementary materials for further details.

These analyses were not preregistered but seemed necessary to ensure the robustness of the analysis.12 See the supplementary materials for a detailed explanation of the rationale of our analysis choice, p-curve, and the intuition behind this method.
One manuscript were on pre-K, and the two others were published after the end of the systematic search and thus could not be included in the review.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We acknowledge the support of the EUR FrontCog grant ANR-17-EURE-0017 as well as of the grant of the Centre de Recherche sur les Inégalités Sociales (CRIS) for funding this research. We are grateful to Lara Narbona Sabaté for her help in reproducing the coding process and to Yannick Savina for his methodological support.
CC acknowledges the support of ANR (ANR-21-CE28-0009).

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: L.C., C.C., and C.B. contributed equally to the study design and conceptualization work. C.C. and L.C. contributed to the funding acquisition. L.C. was in charge of the creation of the theoretical classification, the review design, data collection, data analysis, and validation analysis and wrote the original draft under the supervision of C.C. and C.B..V.T. contributed to the review design and wrote the first script of the pcurve analyses. C.B. and C.C. reviewed and edited the manuscript.

div.head: Competing interests declaration
div.p: The authors declare no competing interest.
